contentrichtext.text: <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Jeremiah1223.jpg|thumb|Jeremiah Green]] --> '''Jeremiah Martin Green''' (born March 4, 1977) is a founding member and drummer of the [[indie rock]] band [[Modest Mouse]] from 1993 to March 2003, and again from July 2004 to present. He was born in [[Oahu, Hawaii]] while his father was in the Army. He grew up in Moxee, WA a few miles outside of [[Yakima]]. His family moved to the Seattle area in 1989. He has an older brother named Adam, a half sister named Theresa and a stepsister. In the mid-1990s, Green also played with the bands [[Satisfact]] on [[K Records]], [[Red Stars Theory]] on [[Touch and Go Records]], and [[Peeved]] on [[Distressed Records]]. Green also plays with a band by the name of [[Vells]], as well as another band named [[Psychic Emperor]]. Both bands play at venues around [[Seattle]] and the [[Pacific Northwest]]. Green can speak a little Japanese, as shown on track 6 of ''[[Night on the Sun]]''. In May 2008, Green released a drum breaks 7" collaboration with [[Plastiq Phantom]] under the alias [[World Gang]] on the [[Imputor|Imputor?]] label. In 2007, Green appeared on Graig Markel's "Via Novella" on the Sonic Boom Label. == Style and influence == Of his work on ''[[Sad Sappy Sucker]]'', Spencer Owen at [[Pitchfork Media]] has said, "Jeremiah Green proves himself to be one of indie rock's best drummers, even this early on in the game."<sup>[http://pitchforkmedia.com/article/record_review/19961-sad-sappy-sucker 1]</sup> In an interview with drummer Benjamin Weikel, he states that Green's drum parts have a "great, loose feeling that's hard to emulate".<sup>[http://www.youaintnopicasso.com/2008/09/29/my-favorite-drummers-benjamin-from-the-helio-sequence/]</sup> He placed 37th in Stylus Magazine's list of "50 Greatest Rock Drummers", where Jonathan Bradley describes his drumming: {{cquote|His rhythms can be as unkempt and intricate as the music they underpin (the rolling shuffle of “Grey Ice Water,” or the stumbling clatter of “Truckers Atlas,” for instance), but they are always strong enough to bolster the momentum of even the most meandering tracks. And when presented with a genuine groove, like the lean, funky “Tiny Cities Made of Ashes,” he forces the band to march in lockstep behind him.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Stylus Magazine's 50 Greatest Rock Drummers|author=Jonathan Bradley|date=30 July 2007|journal=Stylus Magazine}}</ref>}}<sup>[http://www.stylusmagazine.com/articles/weekly_article/stylus-magazines-50-greatest-rock-drummers.htm]</sup> ==References== {{Reflist|1}} ==External links== * [http://www.imputor.com/artists/42/World_Gang_aka_AIDS/ World Gang @ Imputor? Records] * [http://www.psychicemperor.com/ Psychic Emperor official site] * [http://www.myspace.com/vells Vell's MySpace] * [http://www.graigmarkelmusic.com/Graig_Markel_Music/Solo_Home.html Graig Markel's official site] {{ModestMouse}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Green, Jeremiah | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = March 4, 1977 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Green, Jeremiah}} [[Category:1977 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American drummers]] [[Category:Musicians from Washington (state)]] [[Category:Kentwood High School (Washington) alumni]]
